FTR I'm holding off on this because of a [PHP failure](https://sponge.corp.google.com/target?id=1731b0eb-3c40-4c14-8c51-9d336251050c&target=github/grpc/php_linux_opt_native&searchFor=&show=FAILED&sortBy=STATUS) that seems related, which I'm not sure is the cause yet.

Actually, it looks like failures here are all pre-existing.


* asan c++: (scenario: `cpp_protobuf_sync_streaming_from_server_qps_unconstrained_secure_low_thread_count`), https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12510

* basic tests c macos (dbg/opt):
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12960
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12931 (fixed since the test was ran)
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12961
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12932
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12993
 
* basic tests multi-lang linux:
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12978 (fixed since test was last ran)
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12886 (failure related to watch connectivity state, pre-existing)
  - 

* basic tests windows (opt/dbg configs):
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13079
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12964
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13079
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12960
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13091

* msan c:
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12964
  

* portability tests aren't accessible

* tsan C:
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12964
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13090  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12964
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12913
 

* tsan c++:
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12510 (scenario: `cpp_protobuf_sync_streaming_from_server_qps_unconstrained_secure_low_thread_count GRPC_POLL_STRATEGY=epoll1`)
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13089

ubsan C:
  - https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/12964
@apolcyn , is it possible that this also fixed https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/11383? I haven't seen it on Windows since you merged.
I can unfortunately still get the windows timeout to happen, when running under the test infinitely. Perhaps the error is now less frequent, but it seems like it's still there.
